questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent headaches over the past 2 months and partial blindness that started this morning. An MRI of the head shows a 3-cm partially calcified cystic mass located in the suprasellar space. A biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of craniopharyngioma. Further evaluation with quantitative assays shows increased activity of RNA polymerase I. Activity of this enzyme is highest in which of the following areas in the schematic diagram of a cell?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitochondria possess their own DNA (mtDNA) and therefore produce specific mitochondrial mRNA, tRNA, and rRNA. Transcription of mtDNA to mtRNA and translation of mtRNA to mitochondrial proteins are both catalyzed by the mitochondrial RNA polymerase, not by RNA polymerase I.

B) CORRECT:

The nucleolus is a substructure of the nucleus and is only found in eukaryotic cells. RNA polymerase I is exclusively present in the nucleolus, where it performs rRNA transcription. RNA polymerase I catalyzes transcription of 5.8S, 18S, and 28S rRNA. The only rRNA type that is not transcribed by RNA polymerase I (and the only rRNA type that is transcribed outside the nucleolus) is 5S rRNA, which is transcribed by RNA polymerase III.

C) INCORRECT:

The rough endoplasmic reticulum wall is studded with ribosomes, which carry out protein synthesis (translation). Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits does not take place in the rough ER and it does not contain RNA polymerase I.

D) INCORRECT:

Lysosomes contain a variety of enzymes that are responsible for the hydrolysis of intracellular and extracellular compounds. Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits do not take place in the lysosomes, and they do not contain RNA polymerase I.

E) INCORRECT:

The smooth endoplasmic reticulum is involved in the synthesis of new cellular membrane as well as in various catabolic and anabolic pathways (e.g., lipid synthesis). Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits do not take place in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum, and it does not contain RNA polymerase I.

F) INCORRECT:

The nucleus contains the genetic information of a cell (except for mitochondrial DNA). Its nucleoplasm contains RNA polymerases II and III but not RNA polymerase I. Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits do not take place in the nucleus.

G) INCORRECT:

The cell membrane is a lipid bilayer that separates the interior of the cell from the environment. Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits does not take place in the cell membrane, and it does not contain RNA polymerase I.

H) INCORRECT:

The Golgi apparatus mediates transport of proteins and lipids within the cell and contains various enzymes that are responsible for the modification of those compounds (e.g., phosphorylases). Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits does not take place in the Golgi apparatus, and it does not contain RNA polymerase I.
questions.hint: In eukaryotic cells, RNA polymerase I is responsible for the transcription of ribosomal RNA (rRNA), which accounts for the majority of total RNA synthesized in a cell.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She has no particular health concerns. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.2 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
74 μm3


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
30% Hb/cell


Red cell distribution width
14% (N = 13–15)



Genetic analysis shows a point mutation in intron 1 of a gene on the short arm of chromosome 11. A process involving which of the following components is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transfer RNA (tRNA) are specialized RNA adaptors used during protein translation to help build the growing peptide from the mature mRNA template. An intronic mutation will affect transcription or post-transcriptional processing but not translation, since the introns are removed prior to translation.

B) INCORRECT:

MicroRNAs (miRNA) are small molecules that regulate post-transcriptional protein expression by binding to the 3' untranslated region of a target mRNA. Point mutations in the intron of the β-globin gene will not affect miRNA activity.

C) INCORRECT:

TATA-rich nucleotide sequences occur in the promoter region of genes. Beta-thalassemia can be caused by point mutations at the promoter site, which would impair transcription of hnRNA. However, the mutation in this patient is located within the gene on an intron, not at the promoter site; hnRNA will most likely be transcribed in this patient, but processing of hnRNA to mRNA will be affected.

D) INCORRECT:

Heat shock proteins (HSPs) are intracellular protein involved in facilitating and/or maintaining protein folding as well as preventing protein denaturing at high temperatures. The mutation in the intronic DNA occurring in beta-thalassemia traits would directly affect a transcriptional or post-transcriptional process, not a post-translational modification (e.g., protein folding).

E) INCORRECT:

H1 histone proteins are involved in the proper coiling of the DNA necessary for chromatin formation. Proper coiling of DNA regulates the degree of transcription occurring at a particular locus. However, the single point mutation in the intron of the β-globin gene is unlikely to influence H1 histone binding or chromatin structure, which is typically mediated by modifications (e.g., acetylation, methylation) on the histone proteins.

F) CORRECT:

Small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNP) are the subunits of spliceosomes, which are required for proper processing of pre-mRNA (hnRNA). Spliceosomes remove the introns from pre-mRNA through specific splicing sites encoded in introns (AG at the 3' end and GU at the 5' end). Mutations in the intronic splice site of the β-globin locus result in improper splicing, which leads to expression of abnormal β-globin.
Image Description:

Splicing is a posttranscriptional modification of a newly synthesized pre-mRNA molecule. Noncoding gene sequences (introns) are excised from the pre-mRNA molecule and the protein-coding regions (exons) are joined together.
The process involves two transesterification reactions: The first occurs between the 5′ splice site and the 2′ OH of the branch point (A). The second transesterification occurs between the 5′ splice site and 3′ splice site. The process is catalyzed by snRNPs (U1–U6), which together form the spliceosome. The excised intron is released in a lariat structure and the exons are ligated together.
questions.hint: This asymptomatic patient presents with a mild microcytic, hypochromic anemia, a normal red cell distribution width, and a point mutation in the first intron of a gene on the short arm of chromosome 11 (beta-globin locus). These findings are consistent with β-thalassemia minor.

questions.text: An investigator is studying gene expression in a mouse model. She inactivates the assembly of small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs) in anterior horn cells of the spinal cord. Which of the following processes is most likely to be affected as a result?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Protein folding is determined by a protein's primary structure, post-translational modifications, interactions with solvent around the protein, and chaperone proteins. snRNPs are not involved in this process.

B) INCORRECT:

Aminoacylation of tRNA is the process by which adenylated amino acids are covalently bonded to tRNA by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases to form charged tRNAs. snRNPs are not involved in this process.

C) INCORRECT:

DNA ligase joins Okazaki fragments synthesized on the lagging strand during DNA replication. snRNPs are not involved in this process.

D) INCORRECT:

Several proteins, including MLH1 and MSH2, are involved in DNA mismatch repair. snRNPs are not involved in this process.

E) INCORRECT:

Various DNA polymerases (e.g., delta and epsilon) proofread DNA in the 3' to 5' direction during DNA synthesis. RNA polymerase performs this task during transcription. snRNPs are not involved in either process.

F) INCORRECT:

Helicase unwinds the DNA double helix. snRNPs are not involved in this process.

G) CORRECT:

snRNPs combine with a primary transcript to form the spliceosome, a protein-RNA complex that removes introns from hnRNA transcripts and links remaining exons to form mature mRNA. The removal of introns with differential joining of exons (i.e., alternative splicing) can produce several proteins from one gene.

Spinal muscular atrophy refers to a group of diseases caused by mutations in the survival motor neuron (SMN1) gene, which lead to a defect in the assembly of snRNP to form the SMN complex. These mutations ultimately result in apoptosis of lower motor neurons (especially the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord) in the later stages of fetal development and postnatal period. Affected infants present with severe muscle weakness (flaccid paralysis) and generalized hypotonia.
Image Description:

Splicing is a posttranscriptional modification of a newly synthesized pre-mRNA molecule. Noncoding gene sequences (introns) are excised from the pre-mRNA molecule and the protein-coding regions (exons) are joined together.
The process involves two transesterification reactions: The first occurs between the 5′ splice site and the 2′ OH of the branch point (A). The second transesterification occurs between the 5′ splice site and 3′ splice site. The process is catalyzed by snRNPs (U1–U6), which together form the spliceosome. The excised intron is released in a lariat structure and the exons are ligated together.
questions.hint: snRNPs are involved in a process that allows a single genetic sequence to encode several different proteins.

questions.text:
An investigator inoculates three different broths with one colony-forming unit of Escherichia coli. Broth A contains 100 μmol of lactose, broth B contains 100 μmol of glucose, and broth C contains both 100 μmol of lactose and 100 μmol of glucose. After 24 hours, the amounts of lactose, galactose, and glucose in the three broths are measured. The results of the experiment are shown:



Lactose
Galactose
Glucose



Broth A
43 μmol
11 μmol
9 μmol


Broth B
0 μmol
0 μmol
39 μmol


Broth C
94 μmol
1 μmol
66 μmol



The observed results are most likely due to which of the following properties of broth A compared to broth C?

choices.text: Decreased activity of catabolite activator protein
Binding of repressor protein to operator protein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The removal of DNA base pairs by glycosylases is a mechanism of DNA repair but is not involved in the activity of the lac operon and, therefore, does not account for the observed differences in broth A compared to broth C.

B) INCORRECT:

In the lac operon, catabolite activator protein induces the transcription of lac genes to produce enzymes involved in the metabolism of lactose. CAP is activated by cAMP, which is produced by adenylate cyclase when glucose is absent. In broth A, which does not contain glucose, production of cAMP is increased. Thus, broth A has increased, not decreased, activity of CAP compared to broth C, which contains glucose.

C) INCORRECT:

α-Galactosidase A is a lysosomal enzyme that is involved in the degradation of ceramide trihexoside. A deficiency of this enzyme causes Fabry disease but is not involved in the activity of the lac operon and, therefore, does not account for the observed differences in broth A compared to broth C.

D) CORRECT:

The E. coli genome contains the lac operon, a collection of genes that encode enzymes involved in lactose metabolism. The activity of the lac operon is regulated by the presence of lactose and glucose. When lactose is absent, a repressor protein that blocks lac gene transcription is bound to the operator site of the lac operon. When lactose is available, allolactose (an isomer of lactose) inactivates the repressor protein and basal levels of lactose metabolizing enzymes are synthesized. In the absence of glucose, increased activity of adenylate cyclase leads to an increase in the production of cAMP. cAMP activates catabolite activator protein, which induces the transcription of lac genes. When glucose is available, there is little to no conversion of ATP to cAMP by adenylate cyclase and lactose metabolism remains at basal levels. Thus, lac gene expression is highest when lactose is available and glucose is absent.

Broth A, which contains only lactose, facilitates the activation of the lac operon. In the absence of glucose, there is increased activity of adenylate cyclase, which leads to increased production of cAMP, increased activity of catabolite activator protein (CAP), and transcription of lac genes such as lacZ is enhanced. This gene encodes β-galactosidase, an enzyme that hydrolyzes lactose into galactose and glucose. Accordingly, 24 hours after inoculation, broth A contains decreased lactose and increased galactose and glucose.

Broth C, which contains lactose and glucose, facilitates low expression of lac genes. In the presence of lactose, the repressor protein remains unbound to the lac operon. However, in the presence of glucose, the activity of adenylate cyclase decreases. Without cAMP to activate CAP, lac genes are only expressed at basal levels, and E. coli preferentially metabolizes any available glucose. Accordingly, 24 hours after inoculation, broth C contains moderately decreased glucose and only minimal galactose due to low metabolism of lactose.
Image Description:

Operons are functional units of DNA (one or several genes, controlled by a single promoter). The lac operon is the classic example of an operon found in many bacteria (e.g., E. Coli) that contacts the regulatory gene for encoding enzymes responsible for the transport and metabolism of lactose. The operon contains a promoter sequence and an operator sequence that overlaps with the promoter. Depending on the relative levels of lactose and glucose, either the repressor protein binds to the operator (preventing gene transcription) or lactose binds to the repressor protein, which is then inactivated and dissociates from the operator (enabling transcription).

E) INCORRECT:

Binding of a repressor protein to the operator site of the lac operon decreases lac gene transcription, which decreases the production of enzymes that metabolize lactose. When lactose is available, allolactose (an isomer of lactose) inactivates the repressor protein. Broth A and broth C both contain lactose. As a result, both broths promote decreased binding of the repressor protein to the operator site. Thus, this mechanism does not account for the observed differences in broth A compared to broth C.
questions.hint: The LacZ gene of the E. coli genome encodes an enzyme that hydrolyzes lactose into galactose and glucose.

questions.text: A group of investigators is studying the effects of aberrant protein isoforms on the pathogenesis of lung cancer. They observe that three protein isoforms are transcribed from the same 30,160 base-pair-long DNA segment on chromosome 13q. The canonical protein has a primary peptide sequence of 1186 amino acids. The second isoform has 419 amino acids and 100% amino acid sequence homology with the canonical protein. The third isoform has 232 amino acids and 92% amino acid sequence homology with the canonical protein. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the observed phenomenon?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

DNA methylation, typically occurring in CpG islands, is an epigenetic mechanism for modifying the extent of gene expression at a specific locus. Increased methylation often results in the inhibition of transcription. While altered DNA methylation patterns have been implicated in cancer, this process would not explain the observed formation of different protein isoforms from a single locus.

B) INCORRECT:

Site-specific recombination is a type of genetic recombination in which nucleotide sequences (such as mobile genetic elements) are moved between non-homologous sites within a genome. This process would not explain the formation of different protein isoforms from a single gene, as observed in this study.

C) CORRECT:

Alternative splicing is the combination of different exons from a single heterogeneous nuclear RNA (hnRNA) sequence to form different mature mRNA sequences. This process allows a single hnRNA sequence to encode several distinct proteins. This phenomenon explains the transcription of the three protein isoforms from the same 30,160 base-pair-long DNA segment being studied by this group. Disruption in alternative splicing patterns is often associated with neoplasia and metastasis. Many of the affected genes include regulators of apoptosis, hormones, and receptors mediating cell–cell and cell–matrix interactions.

Prokaryotic cells, in contrast, utilize polycistronic gene sequences, in which one mRNA encodes for multiple distinct proteins that are translated synchronously from the large single transcript.

D) INCORRECT:

RNA interference is an epigenetic process in which microRNAs post-transcriptionally target the 3′ untranslated region of specific mRNAs for degradation or translational repression. While altered RNA interference has been implicated in some cancers, this process can not account for the observed formation of different protein isoforms from a single gene.

E) INCORRECT:

Polycistronic genes are responsible for the formation of multiple protein isoforms in prokaryotes. As such, the translation of this mRNA results in multiple distinct proteins, all from different genes, encoded on the same transcript. This process does not occur in eukaryotes, where all mRNAs are monocistronic, and thus would not be observed by the investigators who are studying a single genetic locus.

F) INCORRECT:

Post-translational protein trimming is responsible for the removal of N- or C-terminal propeptides from a zymogen to generate a mature protein. This process can result in shorter AA sequences (e.g., insulin cleavage, pre-procollagen and procollagen cleavage). As the sequence homology is generally conserved during posttranslational modifications, this process cannot explain the formation of the third protein isoform.
questions.hint: This phenomenon is unique to eukaryotic cells and is responsible for the variety of human protein complexity, despite the relative lack of gene diversity in humans.
